messageBody:
--- In junit@egroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentbeck@c...> wrote:
> Declared exceptions are a work of the devil. Seemed like a
> good idea at while Old Nick was explaining them, but now
> the bill is coming due and the benefits are not worth the
> cost. That's just our opinion, but there you have it.
>
Hmmm, so if the code is self-describing, how do I know whether it
might throw an unchecked exception? Comments will go out of sync, and
the more components I bolt together, the more I have to chase through
the details of the logic to see if I've covered everything.
Integrating other people's libraries that use a different exception
convention can be a pig.

As always with Java, they took a useful idea and didn't quite finish
it. In the Modula world, they had a much easier syntax for catching
multiple possible exceptions and a FATAL pragma for ignoring a given
exception type within a compilation scope. Small change, but it made
a difference. They also had well-organised libraries so you didn't
have to specify all the exceptions in the world.

If we must have static typing, then let the compiler do the work --
and let's have the tools take advantage of it. Static typing may be a
pain, but it does give you code completion. Similarly, there's no
reason that an IDE cannot assist with the management of declared
exceptions.

Steve
